The best move according to Yuri Yakovich, and my preference to force the gain of space on the kingside. Otherwise white can play g3
The best move according to Yuri Yakovich, and my preference to force the gain of space on the kingside. Otherwise white can play g3
Critical line. c3 is also interesting

My first real deviation onto theoretical sideroads. Theory dictates that ..b4 is inferior to ..bc, as it closes the position for black on the qs, leaving black's only opportunities on the kingside, while white retains options on both wings. However, this is the reason I wanted to try it: black can focus on the kingside, and does not need to deal with the myriad of additional threats white can make after the flexible ..bc. Black has an advanced f pawn, a semi-open g-file against the castled white king, an active light-square bishop, and is preparing moves like ..Rg8, ..h5,..h4, and even has the option to play ..f5 to increase the mobility of his central pawns. This game is interesting as it demonstrates the practical problems black has to hold his qs together after ..b5. The big problem of course is white's c-pawn, and on reflection I now think as a result of the game and the problems I faced from white playing c5 that it is better to play ..bc
15 ..a5 is also sometimes played

One of white's themes is to attack on the queenside. Sometimes black counters a3 with ..ba followed by ..Rb3 (attacking the undefended bishop on d3), but here ..ba is less effective due to white's Rd1 on move 16
Black wants to close down the queenside, so that he can castle and shortly play ..f5
Black can force the exchange of white's knight after 18.. Nd5 19. Nf3 Nxf3 but the lines I examined where white takes gf (and gets open g-file) were unpleasant

Preventing Ng5, a very unpleasant threat for black
Preventing Ng5, a very unpleasant threat for black
Threatening ..Bg4 (which is not really much of a threat, as white may want to play h3, g4 anyway)
Black is just a few moves too late. If he can get a rook on the c-file he can play ..Rc5 to stop c5
